#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Olango Island
#Text=Olango Island is in Cebu Province , just offshore from ( east of ) Mactan Island and Lapu-Lapu city .
#Text=It is known mainly for its wildlife sanctuary but also has some fine beaches and dive sites .
#Text=The Olango Island Group includes Olango and six smaller islands nearby .
#Text=The main town and main port is Santa Rosa on the west coast .
#Text=Much of the terrain is mangrove swamp , home to large numbers of birds and also , unfortunately , to many mosquitoes .
#Text=Understand
#Text=Olango is fairly densely populated — 30,000 people as of 2010 in about 10 sq km ( 4 sq miles ) — and it is part of Metro Cebu , the country 's second-largest urban region .

#Text=However , it feels distinctly rural ; there are no roads wider than two lanes and many are not paved , there are few buildings higher than two storeys and many one-storey nipa huts , quite a few homes lack running water , and various sorts of livestock run loose .
#Text=Despite the rural impression , Olango is probably not a destination for backpackers on a tight budget ; the accommodation open to tourists is all resorts .
#Text=These are not as expensive as resorts in some other areas , but still more than cheap hotels elsewhere .
#Text=The island lacks things like shopping malls or even a large market ; residents generally go to Lapu-Lapu for those .
#Text=There are sari-sari shops , fruit stalls and barbecue places , and Santa Rosa has a pharmacy and a small hospital with an ambulance , but facilities are generally quite limited .
#Text=Administratively the Olango Group is split like Mactan Island to the west ; the larger northern part is included in Lapu-Lapu city while some of the south is in Córdova Municipality .
#Text=Get in
#Text=There are several ferries , only a few of which carry vehicles .
#Text=The most-used route is from a pier next to the Hilton Hotel on the Lapu-Lapu side to Santa Rosa on Olango .
#Text=Officially , it is the Punta Engaño Pier but locals call it the and taxi drivers may know the destination as Movenpick .
#Text=The resort hotel next to it was Hilton but is now Movenpick .
#Text=An important pier on Olango island itself is the .
#Text=There are also boats from the Hilton pier to Getafe on Bohol .
#Text=Getting to and from the pier is easiest by taxi , about ₱300 from downtown Cebu .
#Text=Mactan-Cebu International Airport is located in Lapu-Lapu , not far from the pier ; a taxi to or from there is only about ₱30 .
#Text=There are also jeepney s that run between the pier area and the airport or Lapu-Lapu and Mandaue cities .
#Text=These boats carry passengers , bicycles , motorcycles and freight , but not cars .
#Text=They seat about 40 people , have outriggers , and look like the photo .
#Text=Cost is ₱15 plus a ₱5 terminal fee and the ride takes about 20 minutes .
#Text=Boats run every half hour or so during daylight hours , but there are fairly often delays while freight is loaded or unloaded .
#Text=The boats do not run in bad weather and are small enough that those with sensitive stomachs may be uncomfortable with even a mild swell .

#Text=Boarding one of these ferries is an interesting experience ; the gangplanks are narrow , they move because one end is on the boat , not all have a railing , and on some the railings or even the floor have gaps .
#Text=However , crew members are very helpful about reaching out with a stabilizing hand where needed , and sometimes two of them will hold up a long bamboo pole to provide a railing .
#Text=There are porters moving freight on and off the boat ; one of them will be happy to handle your luggage for a few pesos .
#Text=There are lots of other boats , mostly smaller than the ferries , around the pier .
#Text=Many offer " island-hopping " trips to some of the smaller islands in the area .
#Text=Boats direct to resorts on Olango can also be arranged , either by contacting the resort ahead of time or just haggling with boat men around the pier .
#Text=There is occasionally a small RoRo ferry between the Hilton and Santa Rosa piers , mainly carrying freight and trucks loaded with freight .
#Text=Get around
#Text=The commonest mode of transport on the island is a motorcycle plus sidecar rig known as a pedicab .
#Text=These are more expensive on the island than elsewhere ; most rides cost ₱120 .
#Text=Bringing your own bicycle or motorcycle would be practical ; the ferries can carry those , traffic on the island is light , and the main roads are mostly paved though often quite narrow .
#Text=You need to drive slowly and watch for potholes , wandering animals , and children playing in the street .
#Text=At night , beware of motorcycles running without lights .
#Text=See
#Text=Olango Wildlife Sanctuary ( South end of the island , in Barangay San Vincente ) .
#Text=A wetland area with many water fowl , very popular with bird watchers ; close to a hundred species are found here , about half of them migratory and half permanent residents .
#Text=It is the only site in the Philippines listed by the Ramsar Convention on Wetlands of International Importance , especially as Waterfowl Habitat .
#Text=Facilities are minimal ; the sanctuary office sells coconut juice and provides a bathroom , but there are no restaurants or accommodation on-site .
#Text=₱20 for Filipinos , ₱100 for others .
#Text=Olango Reef .
#Text=A government-protected fish sanctuary with good snorkelling , located south of Olango around the smaller islands of Nalusuan and Hilutungan .
#Text=It is one of the largest reef areas in the Visayas , about 4.5 km ² .
#Text=Do

#Text=The main dive sites around Olango itself are Mabini Point at the northern tip of the island ( be cautious ; currents here are tricky ) , Baring on the northwest side , and Santa Rosa near the middle of the west side .
#Text=It is also possible to hire a boat to get to various smaller islands nearby ; some of those have good diving .
#Text=The Lapu-Lapu city government organizes a tour they call OMG , Olango my Getaway at ₱999 a person ; it includes transport , some meals , and a night at Triponia Homestay , listed under #Sleep .
#Text=Buy
#Text=There are some handicrafts and shells available from street vendors and in shops at the ferry terminals , but this side of tourism is not well developed .
